description: From Middle English chiken (also as chike > English chick), from Old English ċicen, ċycen (“chicken”), of uncertain origin. Possibly from Proto-West Germanic *kiukīn (“chicken”), or alternatively from Proto-West Germanic *kukkīn, equivalent to cock +‎ -en.

Compare North Frisian schückling (“chicken”), Saterland Frisian Sjuuken (“chicken”), Dutch kuiken (“chick, chicken”), German Low German Küken (“chick”), whence German Küken (“chick”), (elevated, obsolete) German Küchlein (“chick”) and Old Norse kjúklingr (“chicken”).

adjectives.description: chicken (comparative more chicken, superlative most chicken)

examples: Why do you refuse to fight? Huh, I guess you're just too chicken.

entries.meaning: (countable) A domesticated species of junglefowl (usually, Gallus gallus; sometimes, Gallus gallus domesticus or Gallus domesticus), especially so-called when young.
(uncountable) The meat from this bird eaten as food.
(archaic) The young of any bird; a chick.
(countable, slang) A young or inexperienced person.
examples: "This case will make a stir, sir," he remarked. "It beats anything I have seen, and I am no chicken."

entries.meaning: (countable, Polari) A young, attractive, slim man, usually having little body hair; compare chickenhawk.

A confrontational game in which the participants move toward each other at high speed (usually in automobiles); the player who turns first to avoid colliding into the other is the chicken (that is, the loser).
examples: Don't play chicken with a freight train; you're guaranteed to lose.

entries.meaning: A simple dance in which the movements of a chicken are imitated.

verbs.description: chicken (third-person singular simple present chickens, present participle chickening, simple past and past participle chickened)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To avoid a situation one is afraid of.
(UK dialectal or obsolete) plural of chick
